title: S. V. Balasubramanian
text:
Dr. S. V. Balasubramanian is a remote sensing scientist specializing in ocean satellite remote sensing and aquatic optics.
He is currently a Postdoctoral Fellow in the Department of Biology at the University of Massachusetts Boston, where he focuses on hyperspectral modeling of kelp forests and machine learning frameworks for water-quality retrieval.
Previously, he served as a Postdoctoral Fellow at NASA Goddard Space Flight Center (UMD) and GESTAR-II, UMBC, contributing to radiative-transfer modeling and satellite image analysis.
He received his Ph.D. in Ocean Engineering from IIT Madras, India.

Dr. S. V. Balasubramanian


Postdoctoral Fellow, Department of Biology


University of Massachusetts Boston



Dr. S. V. Balasubramanian is a remote sensing scientist specializing in ocean satellite remote sensing and aquatic optics.
He is currently a Postdoctoral Fellow at the University of Massachusetts Boston, working on hyperspectral modeling of kelp forests and machine learning frameworks for water quality retrieval.
Previously, he served as a Postdoctoral Fellow at NASA Goddard Space Flight Center (UMD) and GESTAR-II, UMBC, where his research focused on radiative transfer modeling and satellite image analysis for inland and coastal waters.
He earned his Ph.D. in Ocean Engineering from IIT Madras, India.

Ocean Satellite Remote Sensing

Aquatic Optics and Water Quality

title: Research
text:
Research






Hyperspectral Modeling of Kelp Forests


Developing PRISMA-based hyperspectral models validated using UAV imagery to map kelp canopy structure and health along coastal regions. (Ongoing, UMass Boston)






Machine Learning for Water Quality Retrieval


Applying Mixture Density Networks (MDN) for estimating chlorophyll-a and turbidity from multispectral imagery in optically complex waters. (Collaboration: IIT Madras & NASA/UMBC)






Aquaverse: Atmospheric Correction Framework


Designing a deep learning–based atmospheric correction system for inland and coastal water reflectance retrievals. (Collaboration: NASA & IOCCG)
